description: Salty dried meat that lasts for a long time, but will make you thirsty.
Salty dried fish that lasts for a long time, but will make you thirsty.
Tasty meat that has been heavily smoked for long term preservation.
Tasty fish that has been heavily smoked for long term preservation.
A fluid bladder from a plant based lifeform.  Not very nutritious, but fine to eat anyway.
A smooth white block of cleaned and rendered animal fat.  It will remain edible for a very long time, and can be used as an ingredient in many foods and projects.
A smooth white block of dry-rendered animal fat.  It will remain edible for a very long time, and can be used as an ingredient in many foods and projects.

//: It would help if they thought to add proper storage first.
description: Dehydrated fish flakes.  With proper storage, this dried food will remain edible for an incredibly long time.
Lutefisk is preserved fish that has been dried in a lye solution.  Vile and soap-like yet highly nutritious, it is reminiscent of the afterbirth of a dog or the world's largest chunk of phlegm.
A hefty sausage that has been cured for long term storage.
A hefty long pork sausage that has been cured for long term storage.  Very tasty, if you're in the market for human flesh.
Dried strips of sugary fruit paste.
Betcha can't eat just one.
Some fried seeds of a sunflower, pumpkin or other plant.  Quite nutritious and tasty.
A box of sugary breakfast cereal with marshmallows.  It takes you back to your childhood.
A box of whole-grain wheat cereal.  It's surprisingly good, and allegedly good for your heart.
A box of cornflakes.  They're not that good, but it beats nothing.
Some plain, salted potato chips.
Oh man, you love these chips!  Score!
Salted chips made from corn tortillas, could really use some cheese, maybe some beef.
Plain and unseasoned popcorn.  Not as tasty as other kinds, but healthier as a result.
Popcorn with salt added for extra flavor.
Popcorn with a light covering of butter for extra flavor.
A salty treat of a snack.
A salty treat of a snack, covered in chocolate.
Chocolate isn't very healthy, but it does make a delicious treat.
A handful of squishy, fluffy, puffy, delicious marshmallows.
A concentrated mixture of fat and protein used as a nutritious high-energy food.  Composed of meat, tallow, and edible plants, it provides excellent nutrition in an easy to carry form.
A tasty and nutritious mixture of oats, honey, and other ingredients that has been baked until crisp.
Salty dried pork.  Tastes good, but it will make you thirsty.

//: You could call this change, pointless as it is, a...flavor change.  Ba dum tish.
description: A big bag of peanut butter cups...  your favorite!
A big bag of colorful chocolate filled candies.
A big bag of colorful fruit-flavored chewy candy.
Thin paper tubes of sweet & sour candy powder.  Who thinks of this stuff?
This golden, translucent leaf candy is made with pure maple syrup and melt slowly as you savor the taste of real maple.
Dried mushrooms are a tasty and healthy addition to many meals.
It could be eaten raw if you're desperate, but is much better cooked.
It could be eaten raw if you're desperate, but is much better cooked.
It could be eaten raw if you're desperate, but is much better cooked.
This enriched white flour is useful for baking.
This yellow cornmeal is useful for baking.
Dry flakes of flattened grain.  Tasty and nutritious when cooked, it also doubles as food for horses while dry.
Dehydrated great northern beans.  Tasty and nutritious when cooked, virtually inedible when dry.
Dehydrated long-grain rice.  Tasty and nutritious when cooked, virtually inedible when dry.
A handful of acorns, still in their shells.  Squirrels like them, but they're not very good for you to eat in this state.
A thick slab of salty cured bacon.  Shelf stable, precooked and ready-to-eat, it tastes better when reheated.
Dry and salty, these crackers will leave you quite thirsty.
Dry and sugary, these crackers will leave you thirsty, but go good with some chocolate and marshmallows.
Sweet and delicious cookies, just like grandma used to bake.
A dry and virtually tasteless bread product capable of remaining edible without spoilage for vast lengths of time.
This crunchy, sour topping made from lettuce or cabbage is perfect for your hot dogs and hamburgers, or, if you're desperate, straight to your stomach.
Hard, dry cheese made to last, unlike modern processed cheese.  Will make you thirsty though.
Roasted coffee beans coated with dark chocolate, natural source of concentrated caffeine.
So-called ramen noodles.  Can be eaten raw.
Crunchy sugar in chocolate capsules.  Legal and stimmy.
A big bag of soft chocolate-covered peppermint patties...  yum!
Dehydrated meat flakes.  With proper storage, this dried food will remain edible for an incredibly long time.
Dehydrated human flesh flakes.  With proper storage, this dried food will remain edible for an incredibly long time.
Dehydrated vegetable flakes.  With proper storage, this dried food will remain edible for an incredibly long time.
Dehydrated fruit flakes.  With proper storage, this dried food will remain edible for an incredibly long time.  They are useful for several cooking recipes.
A handful of candy wafers, in assorted flavors: orange, lemon, lime, clove, chocolate, wintergreen, cinnamon, and licorice.  Yum!
Candy sticks.  Slightly more healthy than tobacco cigarettes, but with no possibility of addiction.
Dried salad packed in a box with mayonnaise and ketchup.  Add water to enjoy.

//: Why is this change even needed.  Who is going around making zombie jerky?
description: Pieces of poisonous meat that have been dried to prevent them from rotting away.  It will still poison you if you eat this.
Pieces of poisonous veggy that have been dried to prevent them from rotting away.  It will still poison you if you eat this.
Lean sausage made from heavily salt-cured offal, with natural gut casing.  Waste not, want not.
A pungent garlic bulb.  Popular as a seasoning for its strong flavor.  Can be disassembled to cloves.
Cloves of garlic.  Useful as a seasoning, or for planting.
